prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Map 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum in N22
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a 149 pointing mosaic covering part of the Herschel spectral strip in N22, a region of moderate star formation/radiation field intensity.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have optimized our science for a total investment of ~1 hour of 12m-array time, including overheads. to produce a 149-pointing mosaic map of N22. We have designed the experiment to cover part of the area spectroscopically mapped with Herschel in [CII] and [OI]. This area also has spectroscopic maps from Spitzer IRS (Sandstrom et al. 2012) and deep continuum imaging from Spitzer, Herschel, and LABOCA on Apex, as well as NEWFIRM NIR H2 and Br-gamma, which will aid in the interpretation of the ALMA observations.
Most likely the CO emission will break up in a number of cloudlets with brightness temperatures in the range T ~ 3-30 K (which is already seen in the ACA data at 6"), we use T ~ 3 K at 1.6 arcsec resolution to get the 0.35 Jy line peak flux density. The requested sensitivity, which is close to that afforded by the minimum allowed integration time per pointing, will enable us to complete our science goals and explore the regime where 12CO (2-1) is optically thin.
Using the broad spectral window (1.875 GHz) combined with the wide (468.75 MHz) C18O window we will obtain a continuum sensitivity of ~0.4 mJy. By comparison, the Herschel HERITAGE 500 micron SPIRE images reach a point source sensitivity of ~12 mJy, which even after correcting for the higher dust emissivity at shorter wavelengths yields a factor of ~2 worse mass-sensitivity than what we will reach. Thus, we will be able to detect fainter cold compact sources in dust than any previous survey.
Region Specific: N22 was mapped in 12CO (1-0) using SEST by Rubio et al. (1993), who find a peak integrated intensity of 4 K km/s in their 43 arcsec beam, with a typical linewidth of ~4 km/s. Assuming approximately thermalized emission resulting in a similar brightness temperature for CO (2-1), our requested mosaic sensitivity (0.13 K in 2 km/s bins at 1.6 arcsec resolution, 0.5 pc scales) will yield S/N ~ 20 at the emission peak even in the unlikely case the source is smooth on 43 arcsec scales. The ACA observations show clear detections of both 12CO and 13CO (2-1).

The correlator placement was designed to enhance the science output of this project by simultaneously observing the 12CO, 13CO, and C18O (2-1) transitions, as well as maximizing continuum sensitivity. Although the v(LSR) of our source, N22, is only 120 km/s, the expected velocity gradient and the linewidths are both very small. Therefore it is possible to accomodate three transitions within the passband, with 12CO in the USB and the isotopologues in the LSB. Because the expected S/N for 12CO and 13CO will be high and to fit both windows within the bands, we have chosen a narrow correlator band with a resolution of ~0.08 km/s. Typical 12CO linewidths reported in the SMC at 40"-20" resolution are 3-5 km/s, and the extrapolation of the size-linewidth relation for self-gravitating entities (Bolatto et al. 2008; Heyer & Brunt 2004) to the size scales sampled by these observations (~0.5 pc) yields a chance of v~0.5 km/s. For the C18O line, we've chosen the 468.75 MHz mode with a resoluation of 0.3 km/s which will resolve the narrower ~2 km/s linewidths.

There are no special imaging requirements. The synthesized beam size (nominal theta ~1.6 arcsec) allows us to resolve down to scales of ~0.5 pc and produce a high-quality map. The synthesis will take ~30 min. of on-source (1.0 hr. total) time. The 12m array will be spending close to the minimum integration per mosaic pointing. With at least 36 antennas and 630 baselines, the snapshot uv-plane sampling will be more than adequate to image the source (we are not limited by dynamic range).

Since we have ACA maps for all of the regions from observations taken during Cycle 2 and have single-dish data from APEX for the more extended emission from 12CO (2-1), we will be able to recover line flux on all spatial scales.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Map 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum in SWBarN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a 149 pointing mosaic covering part of the Herschel spectroscopic strip in the North of the SW bar, a region of high star formation/strong radiation field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
See justification for Science Goal #1. We kept the set-up the same for all regions in order to produce a homogenous data set.
Region Specific: This region was mapped in 12CO (2-1) using SEST by Rubio et al. (1993), who find a peak integrated intensity of ~12 K km/s in their 43 arcsec beam, with a typical linewidth of ~3 km/s. Our requested mosaic sensitivity (0.13 K in 2 km/s bins at 1.6 arcsec resolution, 0.5 pc scales) will yield S/N ~ 60 at the emission peak even in the unlikely case the source is smooth on 22 arcsec scales. The ACA observations show clear detections of both 12CO and 13CO (2-1).
We kept the set-up the same for all the regions to produce a homogenous data set; see justification for Science Goal #1.
We kept the set-up the same for all the regions to produce a homogenous data set; see justification for Science Goal #1.
We have ACA observations of the region from Cycle 2 and 12CO (2-1) single-dish data from APEX.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Map 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum in SWBarS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a 149 pointing mosaic covering part of the Herschel spectral strip in the South of the SW bar, a region of low star formation/radiation field intensity.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
See justification for Science Goal #1. We kept the set-up the same for all regions in order to produce a homogenous data set.
Region Specific: This region was mapped in 12CO (1-0) using SEST by Rubio et al. (1993), who find a peak integrated intensity of ~5 K km/s in their 43 arcsec beam, with a typical linewidth of ~4 km/s. Assuming approximately thermalized emission resulting in a similar brightness temperature for CO (2-1), our requested mosaic sensitivity (0.13 K in 2 km/s bins at 1.6 arcsec resolution, 0.5 pc scales) will yield S/N ~ 20 at the emission peak even in the unlikely case the source is smooth on 43 arcsec scales. The ACA observations show clear detections of both 12CO and 13CO (2-1).
We kept the set-up the same for all the regions to produce a homogenous data set; see justification for Science Goal #1.
We kept the set-up the same for all the regions to produce a homogenous data set; see justification for Science Goal #1.
We have ACA observations of the region from Cycle 2 and 12CO (2-1) single-dish data from APEX.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Map 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum in the SW Dark H2 Herschel Pointing
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a 137 pointing mosaic covering the of the Herschel spectral square coverage of a field with a large amount of ``CO-dark'' H2 (based on dust estimates), a region of with no star formation and very low radiation field intensity.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
See justification for Science Goal #1. We kept the set-up the same for all regions in order to produce a homogenous data set.
Region Specific: There is no SEST map of CO in this region. Given the typical value of 4 km/s linewidth of the existing CO observations, we will be able to detect a similar CO emission with integrated intensity of ~2 K km/s at S/N ~ 5 at the sensitivity of our mosaic (0.13 K in 2 km/s at 1.6 arcsec resolution, 0.5 pc scales). The ACA observations show clear detections of both 12CO and 13CO (2-1).
We kept the set-up the same for all the regions to produce a homogenous data set;see justification for Science Goal #1.
We kept the set-up the same for all regions to produce a homogenous data set; see the justification for Science Goal #1.
We have ACA observations of the region from Cycle 2 and 12CO (2-1) single-dish data from APEX.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A dominant reservoir of H2 gas faint in CO emerges as metallicity decreases, which alters the structure of molecular clouds and perhaps the sites of star formation. With ALMA, we can reach the resolution necessary to see the structure of photodissociation regions and the transition from ``CO-bright'' to ``CO-faint'' molecular gas for the first time at 1/5 Solar metallicity in the Small Magellanic Cloud. We propose to map four regions in the Southwest Bar of the SMC at high spatial and spectral resolution (1.6" or 0.5 pc scales and ~0.1 km/s) in 12CO, 13CO, and C18O (2-1). We will determine the mass, structure, and kinematics of molecular clouds across a range of environments and explore the effect of the CO-faint molecular gas on low metallicity star formation. With the slew of ancillary data in hand (much collected by the Co-Is in this proposal), including PAHs, [CII], [CI], [NII], [OI], dust continuum, and dust-based H2 maps, we can fully exploit the ALMA observations. This proposal is a resubmission; only ACA observations were completed in Cycle 2 and our science goals require the higher resolution 12m observations.
